001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.Category;
004import regexodus.Matcher;
005import regexodus.Pattern;
006import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
007import squidpony.squidmath.Arrangement;
008import squidpony.squidmath.IntVLA;
009
010import java.io.Serializable;
011import java.util.ArrayList;
012
013/**
014 * A simple Markov chain text generator; it is called "Limited" because it only can be used as an order-1 Markov chain,
015 * meaning only one prior word is looked at. To use, call {@link #analyze(CharSequence)} once on a large sample text,
016 * then you can call {@link #chain(long)} many times to get odd-sounding "remixes" of the sample text. This is meant to
017 * allow easy serialization of the necessary data to call chain(); if you can store the {@link #words} and
018 * {@link #processed} arrays in some serialized form, then you can reassign them to the same fields to avoid calling
019 * analyze(). One way to do this conveniently is to use {@link #serializeToString()} after calling analyze() once and to
020 * save the resulting String; then, rather than calling analyze() again on future runs, you would call
021 * {@link #deserializeFromString(String)} to create the MarkovTextLimited without needing any repeated analysis.
022 * <br>
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 1/30/2018.
024 */
025@Beta
026public class MarkovTextLimited implements Serializable {
027    private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
028
029    /**
030     * All words (case-sensitive and counting some punctuation as part of words) that this encountered during the latest
031     * call to {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}. Will be null if analyze() was never called.
032     */
033    public String[] words;
034    /**
035     * Complicated data that mixes probabilities and the indices of words in {@link #words}, generated during the latest
036     * call to {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}. This is a jagged 2D array. Will be null if analyze() was never called.
037     */
038    public int[][] processed;
039
040    private static final String INITIAL = "", FULL_STOP = ".", EXCLAMATION = "!", QUESTION = "?", ELLIPSIS = "...";
041    private static final Matcher matcher = Pattern.compile("\\.\\.\\.|[\\.!\\?]|[^\\.!\\?\"\\(\\)\\[\\]\\{\\}\\s]+").matcher();
042    public MarkovTextLimited()
043    {
044    }
045
046    /**
047     * This is the main necessary step before using a MarkovTextLimited; you must call this method at some point before you can
048     * call any other methods. You can serialize this MarkovTextLimited after calling to avoid needing to call this again on later
049     * runs, or even include serialized MarkovTextLimited objects with a game to only need to call this during pre-processing.
050     * This method analyzes the pairings of words in a (typically large) corpus text, including some punctuation as part
051     * of words and some kinds as their own "words." It only uses one preceding word to determine the subsequent word.
052     * When it finishes processing, it stores the results in {@link #words} and {@link #processed}, which allows other
053     * methods to be called (they will throw a {@link NullPointerException} if analyze() hasn't been called).
054     * @param corpus a typically-large sample text in the style that should be mimicked
055     */
056    public void analyze(CharSequence corpus)
057    {
058        Arrangement<String> body = new Arrangement<>(corpus.length() / 5 + 5);
059        body.add(INITIAL);
060        body.add(FULL_STOP);
061        body.add(EXCLAMATION);
062        body.add(QUESTION);
063        body.add(ELLIPSIS);
064        ArrayList<IntVLA> working = new ArrayList<>(corpus.length() / 5 + 5);
065        working.add(new IntVLA(128));
066        int[] links = {0};
067        working.add(new IntVLA(links));
068        working.add(new IntVLA(links));
069        working.add(new IntVLA(links));
070        working.add(new IntVLA(links));
071
072        matcher.setTarget(corpus);
073        int previous = 0, current;
074        while (matcher.find())
075        {
076            current = body.addOrIndex(matcher.group());
077            if(working.size() != body.size())
078            {
079                working.add(new IntVLA(16));
080            }
081            working.get(previous).add(current);
082            if(current > 0 && current < 5)
083            {
084                working.get(current).add(0);
085                previous = 0;
086            }
087            else
088                previous = current;
089        }
090        IntVLA w = working.get(previous), v;
091        if(w.size == 0) w.add(0);
092        final int len = working.size();
093        words = new String[len];
094        body.keySet().toArray(words);
095        processed = new int[len][];
096        w = new IntVLA(128);
097        IntVLA small = new IntVLA(128);
098        IntVLA large = new IntVLA(128);
099        IntVLA probabilities = new IntVLA(128);
100        for(int iv = 0; iv < len; iv++ )
101        {
102            v = working.get(iv);
103            w.clear();
104            probabilities.clear();
105            if(v.size <= 0)
106            {
107                v.add(1);
108            }
109            int vv, sum = 0;
110            final int vs = v.size;
111            OUTER:
112            for (int i = 0; i < vs; ++i) {
113                vv = v.get(i);
114                for (int j = 0; j < w.size; j++) {
115                    if (w.get(j) == vv) {
116                        probabilities.incr(j, 0x10000);
117                        sum += 0x10000;
118                        continue OUTER;
119                    }
120                }
121                w.add(vv);
122                probabilities.add(0x10000);
123                sum += 0x10000;
124            }
125            int iAverage = (sum / w.size);
126
127            small.clear();
128            large.clear();
129            /* Populate the stacks with the input probabilities. */
130            for (int i = 0; i < probabilities.size; i++) {
131                /* If the probability is below the average probability, then we add
132                 * it to the small list; otherwise we add it to the large list.
133                 */
134                if (probabilities.get(i) >= iAverage)
135                    large.add(i);
136                else
137                    small.add(i);
138            }
139
140            processed[iv] = new int[w.size * 3];
141
142            while (!small.isEmpty() && !large.isEmpty()) {
143                /* Get the index of the small and the large probabilities. */
144                int less = small.pop(), less2 = less * 3;
145                int more = large.pop();
146
147                /* These probabilities have not yet been scaled up to be such that
148                 * sum/n is given weight 1.0.  We do this here instead.
149                 */
150                processed[iv][less2] = (probabilities.size * probabilities.get(less)) / (sum >> 16);
151                processed[iv][less2+1] = w.get(less);
152                processed[iv][less2+2] = w.get(more);
153                vv = probabilities.get(less) - iAverage;
154                probabilities.incr(more, vv);
155                if (probabilities.get(more) >= iAverage)
156                    large.add(more);
157                else
158                    small.add(more);
159            }
160            int t;
161            while (!small.isEmpty())
162            {
163                processed[iv][(t = small.pop()) * 3] = 0xFFFF;
164                processed[iv][t * 3 + 1] = processed[iv][t * 3 + 2] = w.get(t);
165            }
166            while (!large.isEmpty())
167            {
168                processed[iv][(t = large.pop()) * 3] = 0xFFFF;
169                processed[iv][t * 3 + 1] = processed[iv][t * 3 + 2] = w.get(t);
170            }
171        }
172    }
173
174    /**
175     * After calling {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}, you can optionally call this to alter any words in this MarkovTextLimited that
176     * were used as a proper noun (determined by whether they were capitalized in the middle of a sentence), changing
177     * them to a ciphered version using the given {@link NaturalLanguageCipher}. Normally you would initialize a
178     * NaturalLanguageCipher with a {@link FakeLanguageGen} that matches the style you want for all names in this text,
179     * then pass that to this method during pre-processing (not necessarily at runtime, since this method isn't
180     * especially fast if the corpus was large). This method modifies this MarkovTextLimited in-place.
181     * @param translator a NaturalLanguageCipher that will be used to translate proper nouns in this MarkovTextLimited's word array
182     */
183    public void changeNames(NaturalLanguageCipher translator)
184    {
185        String name;
186        PER_WORD:
187        for (int i = 5; i < words.length; i++) {
188            if(Category.Lu.contains((name = words[i]).charAt(0)))
189            {
190                for (int w = 5; w < words.length; w++) {
191                    for (int p = 0; p < processed[w].length; p++) {
192                        if (i == processed[w][++p] || i == processed[w][++p])
193                        {
194                            words[i] = translator.cipher(name);
195                            continue PER_WORD;
196                        }
197                    }
198                }
199            }
200        }
201    }
202    /**
203     * Generate a roughly-sentence-sized piece of text based on the previously analyzed corpus text (using
204     * {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}) that terminates when stop punctuation is used (".", "!", "?", or "..."), or once
205     * the length would be greater than 200 characters without encountering stop punctuation(it terminates such a
206     * sentence with "." or "...").
207     * @param seed the seed for the random decisions this makes, as a long; any long can be used
208     * @return a String generated from the analyzed corpus text's word placement, usually a small sentence
209     */
210    public String chain(long seed) {
211        return chain(seed, 200);
212    }
213
214    /**
215     * Generate a roughly-sentence-sized piece of text based on the previously analyzed corpus text (using
216     * {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}) that terminates when stop punctuation is used (".", "!", "?", or "...") or once
217     * the maxLength would be exceeded by any other words (it terminates such a sentence with "." or "...").
218     * @param seed the seed for the random decisions this makes, as a long; any long can be used
219     * @param maxLength the maximum length for the generated String, in number of characters
220     * @return a String generated from the analyzed corpus text's word placement, usually a small sentence
221     */
222    public String chain(long seed, int maxLength) {
223        int before = 0;
224        boolean later;
225        long state;
226        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(1000);
227        int[] rf;
228        while (sb.length() < maxLength) {
229            if(sb.length() >= maxLength - 3)
230            {
231                sb.append('.');
232                break;
233            }
234            later = (before != 0);
235            rf = processed[before];
236            // This is LightRNG's algorithm to generate a random long given sequential states
237            state = ((state = ((state = ((seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) ^ seed >>> 30) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L) ^ state >>> 27) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL) ^ state >>> 31);
238            // get a random int (using half the bits of our previously-calculated state) that is less than size
239            int column = (int) ((rf.length * (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL)) / 0x300000000L) * 3; // divide by 2^32, round down to multiple of 3
240            // use the other half of the bits of state to get a double, compare to probability and choose either the
241            // current column or the alias for that column based on that probability
242            //before = ((state >>> 33) > rf[column]) ? rf[column + 1] : rf[column + 2];
243            if((state >>> 48) <= rf[column])
244                before = rf[column + 1];
245            else
246                before = rf[column + 2];
247            if(before >= 5)
248            {
249                if(sb.length() + words[before].length() + 1 < maxLength)
250                {
251                    if(later)
252                        sb.append(' ');
253                    sb.append(words[before]);
254                }
255                else
256                {
257                    if(sb.length() + 3 <= maxLength)
258                        sb.append("...");
259                    else
260                        sb.append('.');
261                    break;
262                }
263            }
264            else if(before != 0)
265            {
266                sb.append(words[before]);
267                break;
268            }
269        }
270        return sb.toString();
271    }
272
273    /**
274     * Returns a representation of this MarkovTextLimited as a String; use {@link #deserializeFromString(String)} to get a
275     * MarkovTextLimited back from this String. The {@link #words} and {@link #processed} fields must have been given values by
276     * either direct assignment, calling {@link #analyze(CharSequence)}, or building this MarkovTest with the
277     * aforementioned deserializeToString method. Uses spaces to separate words and a tab to separate the two fields.
278     * @return a String that can be used to store the analyzed words and frequencies in this MarkovTextLimited
279     */
280    public String serializeToString()
281    {
282        return StringKit.join(" ", words) + "\t" + Converters.convertArrayInt2D.stringify(processed);
283    }
284
285    /**
286     * Recreates an already-analyzed MarkovTextLimited given a String produced by {@link #serializeToString()}.
287     * @param data a String returned by {@link #serializeToString()}
288     * @return a MarkovTextLimited that is ready to generate text with {@link #chain(long)}
289     */
290    public static MarkovTextLimited deserializeFromString(String data)
291    {
292        int split = data.indexOf('\t');
293        MarkovTextLimited markov = new MarkovTextLimited();
294        markov.words = StringKit.split(data.substring(0, split), " ");
295        markov.processed = Converters.convertArrayInt2D.restore(data.substring(split + 1));
296        return markov;
297    }
298
299    /**
300     * Copies the String array {@link #words} and the 2D jagged int array {@link #processed} into a new MarkovTextLimited.
301     * None of the arrays will be equivalent references, but the Strings (being immutable) will be the same objects in
302     * both MarkovTextLimited instances. This is primarily useful with {@link #changeNames(NaturalLanguageCipher)}, which can
303     * produce several variants on names given several initial copies produced with this method.
304     * @return a copy of this MarkovTextLimited
305     */
306    public MarkovTextLimited copy()
307    {
308        MarkovTextLimited other = new MarkovTextLimited();
309        other.words = new String[words.length];
310        System.arraycopy(words, 0, other.words, 0, words.length);
311        other.processed = new int[processed.length][];
312        int len;
313        for (int i = 0; i < processed.length; i++) {
314            other.processed[i] = new int[len = processed[i].length];
315            System.arraycopy(processed[i], 0, other.processed[i], 0, len);
316        }
317        return other;
318    }
319}
